A very nice and competitive game. Aiming with mouse only allows you to go up and down and aiming with arrow keys allows you to go from left to right. This makes the game very competitive and I could even consider this game as a E-sports breakthrough. I would say that this is the flagship which made CS:GO.

TL;DR: Small, but kind of fun minigame. Buy it on sale if you want, but otherwize don't spend 5$ on it.

Eh...

This game was never meant to be a big IP for Valve; it was just squirted out in a random Half-Life update back in 2000, and is really more of a simple experiment to see how easy it was to make a mod on the then-new Goldsrc engine. In light of this scenario, I judge this game only as a small, almost minigame you can buy for 49 pennies on sale. (5 US Dollars otherwise.)

Some Valve games, like Half-Life, have an overarching story that progresses throughout its campaign and shapes itself according to the player's actions. Some Valve games, like Left 4 Dead, have an easily-explainable backstory that explains the events of the main game. In Ricochet, the story is, you are throwing discs at each other on floating platforms in space. There is no explanation, there is no exposition; but neither does there really need to be. You are simply throwing discs at each other on floating platforms in space. Nothing else needs to be said.

The game is fairly rudamentary, featuring less than a handful of multiplayer maps and only (AFAIK) two gameplay modes; good old-fashioned deathmatch, and arena, featuring two players facing off in a number of best-of rounds. The gameplay is simple yet engaging - all players are armed only with three regenerating discs used to knock each other off their platforms, usually meeting their dooms in a death screen you will see very, very often. You can also throw powered discs to decapitate opponents instead. Aside from a couple of disc power-ups, that's it. It is a very easy to learn game.

As far as multiplayer compatability is concerned in 2019, you can (usually) find at least one server with a couple of players on it for a quick game.

Unless you really want it, however, I would suggest only purchasing it on sale.

I recently got Ricochet from the "Valve Complete Pack". While looking through the list of games I got from the pack I spotted this game. I didn't know what to think of it, because I had never heard or knew of this game. I felt like I should've known about it due to it had been made by Valve, but no nothing came to mind. So after I bought the pack I decided to check this game out first to see what its was. Upon booting up the game I went to the server browser to see if I could join a game, but when I looked at the list of servers, they were all empty apart from one. One other person in the whole world was by himself waiting for someone to join him. I join this persons server loaded in, and was instantly confused.

The way the game is played by throwing discs at the enemy player and either kill them or push them off the map, all depends on the power ups you get and you can only shoot disc's forward. The map you and the enemy fight in is confusing, its not like a normal map but it's a series of circular platforms and the way you navigate through out the map is by standing on arrows that will either take you to the next platform or bounce you to the upper platforms.

The game is actually pretty fun though I dunno what it is, but I kinda find the game eerie. The skybox is a dark and purple void with no music, and when you fall off the map, your camera will snap above you and start to spin faster and faster as your character screams as he disappears into the nothing.

A big problem with the game is that it is dead. I was lucky to get a match with another player, so I recommend if you get this game, see if your friend will get it with you and play it together.

Ricochet vio la luz como un mod de Half Life. Fue desarrollado por Valve y publicado el 1 de Noviembre del 2000.
Es un juego FPS de estilo Deathmatch inspirado por viejos videojuegos arcade. Tomó como guía principal para su desarrollo a la película "Tron" y a su videojuego "Discs of Tron" (Juego arcade estrenado en 1983).
El objetivo del juego es ir saltando de una plataforma en otra lanzando discos a los rivales para hacerlos caer al vacío. Con el click izquierdo se lanza un disco recto, y con el derecho un disco potente que puede decapitar al rival que se tenga enfrente. Cada vez que caiga un enemigo, con un lanzamiento directo sumaremos un punto, y si hacemos rebotar el disco contra las paredes, dos puntos. Además, en Ricochet los discos pueden tener cinco poderes diferentes provenientes de un power-up que flota en el centro del mapa: "power shot", "freeze shot", "fast shot", "triple shot" y "dragon's fury".
Este juego trae solo tres mapas para poder jugar: uno estilo arena y dos estilo deathmatch.

La verdad que no lo recomiendo. Una de las razones es porque la idea del videojuego no es original y, si bien es entendible que Valve haya querido basarse en un estilo de juego ya creado para aplicarlo en su producción, no termina de convencer la manera en que fue llevada a cabo para acompañar al videojuego y a lo que este quiere transmitir al jugador. Solo fue una idea que quedó estancada y nada más.
Otro de los puntos criticables es que no contiene nada de música que acompañe al título.
También considero que Ricochet es un desarrollo pésimo de Valve porque no hay personajes con carisma a quienes recordemos ni tampoco una historia, más que nada porque la empresa nos tiene acostumbrados a ese tipo de cosas en sus títulos. Somos un hombre que tiene que saltar en plataformas y tirar a sus rivales al vacío, idea antes vista en un videojuego de máquina arcade. Solamente es un juego para jugar con amigos y soltar alguna que otra risa por 1 hora o un poco más.

Si lo desean comprar, que sea con el pack de Valve, pero sino pasenlo por alto.

Move over Half-Life and make way for the crowning achievement of the Valve software library: Ricochet! Drawing inspiration from the science fiction classic Tron, Ricochet brings pulse-pounding, disc-throwing action into your home. Vibrant graphics powered by Valve's state-of-the-art GoldSrc engine will dazzle you and an easy-to-use online interface makes matchmaking a breeze. Highly recommended.
